```python
import os
import requests
import json


def handler(pd: "pidedream"):
    try:

        token = os.environ['GITHUB_TOKEN']
        user = "github_username"
        repo = "github_repo"
        event_type = "deploy"
        headers = {
            "User-Agent": "@elog/serverless-api",
            "Accept": '*/*',
            "Authorization": f"token {token}",
        }
        response = requests.post(
            f"https://api.github.com/repos/{user}/{repo}/dispatches",
            headers=headers,
            data=json.dumps({"event_type": event_type})
        )
        # response.raise_for_status()
        print(response.text, response.json())
        return {"message": response.json() or 'Success!'}
    except Exception as e:
        print(e)
```

> ğŸ’¡Â **What is log buffer?**


	The log buffer is the memory area that holds data to be written to the log files on disk. Log buffer size is defined by theÂ [`innodb_log_buffer_size`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_log_buffer_size)Â variable. The default size is 16MB. The contents of the log buffer are periodically flushed to disk. A large log buffer enables large transactions to run without the need to write redo log data to disk before the transactions commit. Thus, if you have transactions that update, insert, or delete many rows, increasing the size of the log buffer saves disk I/O.


	TheÂ [`innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit)Â variable controls how the contents of the log buffer are written and flushed to disk. TheÂ [`innodb_flush_log_at_timeout`](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-parameters.html#sysvar_innodb_flush_log_at_timeout)Â variable controls log flushing frequency.

![MySQL 8.0ç‰ˆæœ¬](https://image.kuangyichen.com/image/innodb-architecture-8-0.png)


> An undo log is a collection of undo log records associated with a single read-write transaction. An undo log record contains information about how to undo the latest change by a transaction to aÂ [clustered index](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_clustered_index)Â record. If another transaction needs to see the original data as part of a consistent read operation, the unmodified data is retrieved from undo log records. Undo logs exist withinÂ [undo log segments](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_undo_log_segment), which are contained withinÂ [rollback segments](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_rollback_segment). Rollback segments reside in theÂ [system tablespace](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_system_tablespace), inÂ [undo tablespaces](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_undo_tablespace), and in theÂ [temporary tablespace](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/glossary.html#glos_temporary_tablespace).

	**clustered index**


	TheÂ `InnoDB`Â term for aÂ _**primary key**_Â index.Â `InnoDB`Â table storage is organized based on the values of the primary key columns, to speed up queries and sorts involving the primary key columns. For best performance, choose the primary key columns carefully based on the most performance-critical queries. Because modifying the columns of the clustered index is an expensive operation, choose primary columns that are rarely or never updated.

	A collection ofÂ _**undo logs**_. Undo log segments exists withinÂ _**rollback segments**_. An undo log segment might contain undo logs from multiple transactions. An undo log segment can only be used by one transaction at a time but can be reused after it is released at transactionÂ _**commit**_Â orÂ _**rollback**_. May also be referred to as anÂ â€œundo segmentâ€.
